> >
>Yes the parameters are all correct and I agree that it seems counter
>intuitive. Actually I think you answered this question yourself in your
>response to John -  crossover. The crossover rate was set to 0.5, so
>structures are continuously propagating through the population.
>Subtractive mutations are only on individual [offspring] genomes, so
>there is a very high probability that the deleted gene will exist in
>numerous other genomes in the population and will persist despite
>subtractive mutations occuring. In fact the propagation of genes through
>crossover is so numerous that the subtractive mutations have hardly any
>effect at all - as demonstrated in the graphs.

Doesn't NEAT crossover also, when one individual has a gene and the other 
not, always include the gene in the offspring?

That means that a deletion cannot spread to other individuals and be 
combined with other deletions.

>As a side note I was just reading a short article in this month's
>Scientific American that briefly discusses the possibility that
>crossover, despite being being good at trying out combinations of genes,
>actually acts as an error correcting technique - that is, if one of the
>parents has a mutated gene that is poor, the other parent is likely to
>have a good copy, and therefore some of the offspring will have a
>complete set of good genes despite having a parent with a mutation.
>Well, it's sort of relevant :)

It's very probably true but less significant than it sounds.  Calling what 
cross over does "error correcting" is based on a supposition that the 
mutation is "wrong" in some way.  Another view is that any mutation is 
advantageous, disadvantageous or neutral.  Most are neutral, then 
disadvantageous and finally a tiny minority are advantageous (because 
modern species are already "highly evolved").  What crossover does is to 
mix mutations which originate in either parent into one offspring.  Thus:

1) neutral mutations recombine purely at random.

2) advantageous and disadvantageous mutations recombine according to their 
dominant/recessive nature (sexual species are generally have two copies of 
each gene).  In the simplest cases one copy of the gene simply "works 
better" than the other.  This makes it the dominant one (because the 
presence of a less-efficient or broken alternative form does not impair the 
good one).

[[dominant mutations affect the individual fully, even with only one copy 
present, recessive genes only affect the individual when both chromosomes 
carry them]]

3) So recessive disadvantages are selected against only when two copies 
appear.  This makes only in a way which can be determined by examination of 
its descendents (is there a word for this?).  So it's not so much unfit 
itself, more an "unfitness carrier".

4) Advantageous recessive genes are selected for a single copy but have no 
further pressure to add the second copy (except for the same sort of 
"fitness carrier" for the offspring, as just mentioned).

So, this leaves us with the idea that crossover allows advantageous genes 
_from different parents_ to be shuffled together into the same 
chromosome.  Thus allowing a descendant to carry both of them.  Which is 
going to work exactly the same whether the unfit genes are 'mutations' or 
whether they are the 'normal' copy, slowly being replaced by the fitter 
'mutation'...

Note that in nature, crossover occurs during gametogenesis (sperm/egg 
creation) so that it's only after an individual has proven fit that the 
chromosomes it got from its parents are recombined, ready for its own 
children...

>I think it makes sense. If a species is good but has not improved for a
>number of generations (200 in the experiments) then it is culled.

This is presumably the wrong thing to do?  I mean, given that the fitness 
function is the only measure of progress that we have, then the fittest 
species _is_ the best solution we have. however much we would also like it 
to also have the property of still evolving.  The only thing we can do is 
to continue taking mutants of it (and other fit species) and hope that 
eventually an avenue of progress is found.

This is where neutral mutations might come into their own.  Neutral 
mutations allow the system to continue exploring, even when it does no know 
which way is uphill.  This can happen two ways:

1) accumulation of diversity in the population (whether you choose to call 
it more than one species is up to you)

2) genetic drift -- this is the simple random walk of the genome when 
subjected to a series of mutation with no selection pressure.

So, reassure me that your approaches do allow neutral mutations to prosper...
